Graphical abstract N-heterocyclic carbene CO2 adducts (NHC–CO2) are typical zwitterionic ionic liquid compounds, known for their strong nucleophilicity and significant catalytic ability. However, NHC–CO2 is sensitive to water, and its complex and polluting preparation process limits its widespread application. Furthermore, most reported NHC–CO2 compounds function as homogeneous catalysts, posing considerable challenges for separation. In this study, an in-situ green synthesis method was employed to develop a heterogeneous NHC–CO2 catalyst, PS–IMIL. This approach not only prevents direct contact between the catalyst and water but also simplifies the preparation process and mitigates environmental pollution. The synthesis conditions of PS–IMIL were optimized, and its structure and properties were analyzed. Furthermore, the synthesis mechanism of PS–IMIL was investigated, and its kinetics were also studied. The results indicate that the interaction between the material ethylene carbonate (EC) and the precursor is crucial for the in-situ synthesis of PS–IMIL. The prepared PS–IMIL not only preserves the catalytic ability of NHC–CO2 but also exhibits characteristics of being metal- and halogen-free. Remarkably, the catalytic activity and structure of PS–IMIL remain unchanged after 300 h of continuous use in dimethyl carbonate (DMC) production. Compared to similar catalysts, PS–IMIL exhibits excellent catalytic activity and stability. This study provides a solid theoretical and practical reference for the development of heterogeneous NHC–CO2 catalysts. The synthesized PS–IMIL demonstrates significant potential for the industrial production of DMC and other carbonate esters. Keywords In-situ Catalyst Synthesis NHC–CO2 Transesterification Dimethyl Carbonate Continuous Production Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Dimethyl carbonate (DMC) is an environmentally friendly multifunctional chemical that has garnered considerable attention in various fields, including chemistry, medicine, and energy [1,2]. Owing to its excellent solubility and low viscosity, DMC plays a crucial role in lubricant additives, synthetic fragrances, and solvent-based dyes [3,4]. Its diverse functional groups enable it not only to serve as a methylation and carbonylation reagent [5] but also as an intermediate in various organic and pharmaceutical syntheses [6]. Additionally, the high charge-transfer capability and low flammability of DMC make it suitable as an electrolyte in lithium-ion batteries and supercapacitors [7]. Currently, the transesterification of CO2-derived ethylene carbonate (EC) and methanol (MeOH) is regarded as the most efficient method for DMC production, owing to its mild reaction conditions and environmental benefits [8]. This process also co-produces ethylene glycol (EG), thereby enhancing material utilization [9,10]. However, the choice of catalysts significantly influences the quality of the final product [11,12]. Traditional catalysts, such as alkali metal hydroxides [13], metal oxides [14], supported catalysts [15], hydrotalcite [16], zeolites [17], and ion-exchange resins [18], often face challenges like complex synthesis procedures, low catalytic activity, and environmental concerns. In contrast, organic catalysts, particularly ionic liquids, show great promise for improving transesterification efficiency and minimizing residual metal ions in the product [19,20]. Nonetheless, the use of halogen-containing ionic liquids can lead to equipment corrosion and solid waste generation. Therefore, the development of halogen-free ionic liquids for use in transesterification reactions has attracted considerable attention recently [21–23]. N-heterocyclic carbene CO2 adduct (NHC–CO2), or NHC-carboxylate, is a typical zwitterionic ionic liquid compound. Under thermal conditions, the carboxylic acid group in NHC–CO2 will escape as gaseous CO2, resulting in the formation of free N-heterocyclic carbenes (NHC) [24,25]. The carbene C atom in NHC possesses a lone pair of electrons in its sp2 orbital, which contributes to its strong nucleophilicity and makes it widely used in molecular catalysis [26–28]. For instance, Kayaki et al. [29] employed NHC–CO2 as a catalyst, successfully utilizing it for the conversion of CO2 into cyclic carbonates. The results indicated that NHC–CO2 exhibits strong nucleophilicity and alkalinity, resulting in an excellent catalytic effect. Wang et al. [30] prepared a nano-copolymer containing the NHC–CO2 functional group and successfully employed it in CO2 cycloaddition, the results indicated that NHC–CO2 is crucial in the ring-opening of epoxides, and its catalytic activity is comparable to halogen-containing catalysts. Additionally, Su et al. [31] synthesized four NHC–CO2 compounds with various alkyl side chains for the hydration of ethylene oxide to prepare EG. The results demonstrated that these compounds exhibited similar catalytic effects to traditional catalysts like Na2CO3 and NaHCO3, while outperforming existing ring-opening catalysts such as 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide and 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide (BmimBr). Wang et al. [32] reported the application of NHC–CO2 in the catalytic synthesis of dimethyl carbonate DMC and the results demonstrate that the carboxylic acid group can efficiently enhance the conversion of methanol (MeOH) to the methoxy group. Although NHC–CO2 demonstrates excellent catalytic activity for various organic reactions, it can react with water [33], leading to deactivation upon contact with water or exposure to moisture. Additionally, the existing preparation methods for NHC–CO2 still rely on traditional approaches, which have several significant drawbacks, including complex procedures, stringent synthesis conditions, generation of acid–alkali solid waste, and negative environmental consequences. Moreover, the reported NHC–CO2 catalysts are mainly homogeneous, posing considerable challenges in terms of catalyst separation and product purification. Although some heterogeneous NHC–CO2 catalysts have been reported [34], their complex preparation processes pose significant challenges to industrial development. Consequently, there is substantial research value in devising a simple and eco-friendly method for synthesizing heterogeneous NHC–CO2 catalysts. In this study, the interaction between the reactant ethylene carbonate (EC) and the precursor methanol (MeOH) is harnessed to develop an in-situ technique for green catalyst synthesis. As a result, a heterogeneous NHC–CO2 catalyst, PS–IMIL, has been successfully developed. This catalyst is free of metal and halogen and exhibits strong alkalinity and excellent catalytic ability. The proposed method streamlines the catalyst preparation process, enhances catalyst production efficiency, and prevents acid–base solid waste generation typically associated with traditional NHC–CO2 preparation methods. The structures and properties of the synthesized PS–IMIL were analyzed qualitatively and quantitatively using various characterization techniques. The synthesis mechanism of PS–IMIL was deduced, and the synthesis conditions were optimized. Furthermore, the conditions for transesterification between EC and MeOH catalyzed by PS–IMIL were optimized, and the stability of the optimized catalyst was estimated. In addition, the applicability of PS–IMIL on various substrates was investigated. Combined with the thermogravimetric–mass spectrometry (TG–MS) results, the transesterification reaction mechanism of EC and MeOH catalyzed by PS–IMIL was elucidated, and the reaction kinetic properties were studied. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of the catalyst Preparation of precursor PS-IM: 10 g of PS-Cl was added in acetonitrile and stirred for 1 h, then 4 g of imidazole was dissolved in the above solution and stirred for 24 h. After that, the resulting precursor was washed with acetonitrile and dried at –0.1 MPa, 70 °C for 12 h, and the precursor was named PS-IM. In-situ synthesis of PS-IMIL: 4 g PS-IM was added in a fixed-bed reactor, then the reactants (EC and MeOH, the molar ratio is 6: 1) were fed at different times and temperatures to produce the target catalyst and it has been named PS-IMIL. The synthesis process of PS-IM and PS-IMIL are shown in Fig. 1 , while the temperature operation procedure of the fixed-bed reactor is displayed in Fig. S1. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Innovation in catalyst preparation A sample statement is provided to illustrate the difference between traditional and innovative methods in catalyst preparation. As shown in Fig. 2 , traditional NHC-CO2 catalysts often suffer from five major challenges, including difficulties in storage, environmental pollution, complex preparation processes, susceptibility to deactivation, and challenges in separation. Specifically, NHC-CO2 is prone to decomposing into NHC and CO2 upon heating, and the highly reactive NHC can subsequently react with H2O in the air, leading to deactivation. This poses significant challenges for storage and transportation [33]. During the synthesis of NHC-CO2, strongly corrosive bases (such as KOtBu and NaH) are often employed, leading to environmental pollution and the formation of solid waste [35]. Additionally, the use of volatile solvents further intensifies the pollution problem. The traditional procedure for preparing NHC-CO2 requires high temperatures and pressures, along with specialized equipment that can withstand pressure and corrosion [36]. This undeniably increases the economic burdens and limits the potential for large-scale development. Notably, NHC-CO2 can react with organic compounds [37], resulting in the loss of active sites. Additionally, dimer formation is another cause of NHC-CO2 deactivation [34]. Furthermore, the separation of homogeneous catalysts also limits the development of NHC-CO2. This study proposed the catalyst synthesis technique effectively addresses the drawbacks of traditional methods. The precursor PS-IM is placed in a fixed-bed reactor, and then the reactants (EC and MeOH) are introduced. PS-IM can directly react with EC to generate the structure of NHC–CO2, which significantly shortens the catalyst synthesis procedure. Notably, the reaction between PS-IM and EC achieved 100 % atom utilization, and this process does not require other substances or catalysts, thus preventing environmental pollution and economic burden. In particular, the catalyst reported in this work is generated within the fixed-bed reactor, which not only eliminates the impact of H2O and CO2 from the air and avoids interference from other chemicals. Therefore, this study provides an alternative for synthesizing the NHC-CO2 catalyst, and the resulting heterogeneous NHC-CO2 catalyst (PS-IMIL) demonstrates excellent catalytic activity and stability in practical applications. 3.2 Qualitative and quantitative analyses of PS–IMIL 3.2.1 Solid-state 13C NMR analysis Solid-state 13C NMR analysis was used to investigate the structure of PS–IMIL (Fig. 3 ). The chemical shifts of the C atoms of the imidazole ring are observed at 12, 13, and 14 ppm. Additionally, PS–IMIL exhibits a typical peak at 229 ppm, assigned to the N–COO– group [32], suggesting the formation of the NHC–CO2 group. Notably, solid-state 13C NMR is affected by various factors, such as the sample morphology, crystal structure, and molecular interactions, which can result in overlapping peaks and peak shifts [38]. Therefore, Fourier–transform infrared (FT–IR) spectroscopy was used to further analyze the structure of PS–IMIL. 3.2.2 FT-TR and XPS analyses The chemical structure of PS–IMIL was analyzed via FT-IR spectroscopy (Fig. 4 (a)). A distinct characteristic peak of PS–Cl is observed in the range of 1260–1280 cm−1, which is attributable to the stretching vibration of the C–Cl bond [12]. Compared with PS–Cl, the peaks of the stretching vibration of the C–Cl bond in PS–IM and PS–IMIL almost disappear, indicating that the Cl element is replaced by the imidazole molecule. However, owing to the high polymerization degree of PS–Cl, imidazole molecules are too large to enter the pores of PS–Cl, resulting in an incomplete reaction. In addition, PS–IM and PS–IMIL demonstrate two new peaks at 701 and 1558 cm−1, corresponding to the stretching vibrations of C–N and C = N, respectively [39,40]. This indicates that imidazole molecules are bonded to the polystyrene resin through covalent bonds. In particular, a new characteristic peak observed at 1674 cm−1 in PS–IMIL is ascribed to the stretching vibration of the C = O bond, indicating the formation of the NHC–CO2 group [31]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to characterize the elemental compositions of PS–IMIL. The XPS survey spectrum (Fig. 4 (b)) reveals that PS–IMIL predominantly comprises four elements carbon (C), nitrogen (N), oxygen (O), and chlorine (Cl) elements. Among them, the presence of Cl is attributed to an incomplete reaction. Fig. 4 (c) displays the N 1 s spectra of PS–IMIL. The peaks at 398.7 and 396.5 eV belong to the NR3 and = N– groups, respectively [41,42], which are consistent with the chemical environment of N in the imidazole ring. The peak at 399.5 eV is assigned to the R4N+ group [43], and this special quaternary ammonium group indicates that PS–IM is successfully activated by EC. Fig. 4 (d) shows the O 1 s spectrum of PS–IMIL. The peaks observed at 527.2 and 529.6 eV are attributable to the C–O and C = O bonds, respectively. According to a previous study [31], these results indicate the existence of the NHC–CO2 group in PS–IMIL. 3.2.3 TG–DTA analysis Further, the thermal stability of PS–IMIL was studied, and the corresponding TG–differential (TG) and differential thermal analysis (DTA) curves are shown in Fig. 5 (a). With an increase in temperature, PS–IMIL exhibits four decomposition stages, and the corresponding DTA curves show a decreasing trend. This suggests that the four decomposition stages are endothermic. The first decomposition stage ranges from room temperature to 126.5°C, with a mass loss of 3.5 %, attributed to the volatilization of residual reactants and adsorbed water. The second decomposition stage occurs from 126.5°C to 258.8°C, with a mass loss of 5.3 %. Combined with the TG–MS results (Fig. 5 (b)), the thermal decomposition products obtained in the second decomposition stage are determined to be H2O (m/z = 18), C2H6 (m/z = 30), and CO2 (m/z = 44). Therefore, the second decomposition stage corresponds to the thermal decomposition of the carboxyl group and alkyl side chain in the quaternary ammonium group. The carboxyl group decomposes into CO2, while the alkyl side chain decomposes into H2O and C2H6. With continuous heating up to 388.9°C, the third decomposition stage is observed, with a mass loss of 17.4 %. According to the TG–MS results, a peak at m/z = 68 is observed in this stage. Therefore, the third decomposition stage is attributable to the thermal decomposition of the imidazole rings. As the temperature reaches 600°C, the fourth decomposition stage occurs, leading to a mass loss of 47.9 %. According to the TG–MS results, several peaks with relatively large charge–mass ratios are observed in this stage. Among them, the peak at m/z = 78 is attributed to the benzene ring, while the peak at m/z = 92 is assigned to toluene. The remaining peaks at m/z = 105 and m/z = 115 are likely associated with macromolecules produced by resin decomposition. Finally, approximately 23.5 % mass remains, attributable to C deposition. 3.2.4 SEM–EDS analysis The micromorphology of the synthesized catalyst was analyzed via scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Fig. 6 (a–b) show the SEM images of PS–Cl at different magnifications, revealing a smooth and flat surface. Meanwhile, Fig. 6 (c) indicates that the surface of PS–IM is noticeably rougher than that of PS–Cl, which is attributed to the covalent bonding of imidazole to the surface of the polystyrene resin beads. Notably, Fig. 6 (d–e) demonstrates that PS–IMIL exhibits the highest roughness than PS–Cl and PS–IM, indicating the formation and accumulation of active sites. Fig. 6 (f and g) shows the energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) spectrum of PS–IMIL, aiming to clarify the element distribution. The results indicate that PS–IMIL predominantly comprises C, N, O, and Cl elements, which is consistent with the XPS results. Moreover, the uniform distributions of N and O elements suggests a consistent dispersion of active sites on the surface of PS–IMIL. Additionally, the EDS analysis reveals that the N and O contents of PS–IMIL are 7.6 % and 14.3 %, respectively. The N: O molar ratio is approximately 2: 3, which aligns with the structure of PS–IMIL. To confirm these results, an organic element analysis was conducted, and the results show that the C, N, O, and H contents of PS–IMIL are 63.4 %, 7.8 %, 14.8 %, and 6.7 %, respectively. Additionally, the N: O molar ratio is also close to 2: 3. These findings suggest the existence of the NHC–CO2 group in PS–IMIL. 3.3 Mechanism for in-situ synthesis of PS–IMIL The target product of the transesterification of EC and MeOH is DMC. In theory, EC and DMC can react with PS–IM. Therefore, a control experiment was performed to verify whether EC or DMC reacted with PS–IM in the in-situ synthesis of PS–IMIL. As a result, two samples of PS–IM/EC and PS–IM/DMC are obtained. As shown in Fig. S2, PS–IMIL and PS–IM/EC display the same FT-IR spectra, indicating that they have the same chemical structure. The TG–DTA curves of PS–IM/EC and PS–IM/DMC are shown in Fig. S3. The results indicate that PS–IM/EC exhibits four decomposition stages, similar to the results of PS–IMIL. The catalytic performances of PS–IM/EC and PS–IM/DMC are shown in Fig. S4, as well as the catalytic performance of PS–Cl is shown in Fig. S5. The results indicate that when PS–IM/EC is used as a catalyst, the EC conversion, DMC selectivity, and DMC yield are approximately 76.7 %, 86.5 %, and 66.4 %, respectively. Meanwhile, using PS–IM/DMC as a catalyst, the EC conversion, DMC selectivity, and DMC yield are approximately 42.8 %, 51.9 %, and 22.1 %, respectively. When PS–IMIL is used as the catalyst, the EC conversion is 76.2 %, with the DMC selectivity and yield of 88.7 % and 67.6 %, respectively. These results imply that PS–IMIL and PS–IM/EC display extremely similar catalytic activities and that EC plays a pivotal role in PS–IM activation. Therefore, the in-situ synthesis mechanism of PS–IMIL was proposed, and the details are shown in Fig. 7 . The N atom at position 3 of the imidazole ring in PS–IM exhibits strong nucleophilicity due to the presence of a lone pair of electrons. The O atom of the carbonyl group (C = O) in EC has greater electronegativity and can attract π electrons, making it conducive to reactions with nucleophiles. Therefore, EC will undergo a ring-opening reaction and readily undergo an SN2 reaction with the N atom at position 3 of the imidazole ring to produce an intermediate product (I) with a special carbene structure at high temperatures. However, the carbene C atom has a lone pair of electrons in its sp2 orbital, which endows it with a strong nucleophilic ability. Moreover, carbonyl C atoms in intermediate I still retain considerable electrophilicity. Therefore, the C–O bond connected to the carbonyl group in intermediate I will break and undergo nucleophilic rearrangement as well as a proton-transfer reaction with the C atom at position 2 of the imidazole ring [44], resulting in the formation of the stable product PS–IMIL. The mechanism of PS–IM activation by DMC is illustrated in Fig. S5. 3.4 Optimization of PS–IMIL synthesis The catalyst synthesis conditions were optimized. Fig. 8 (a) shows the effect of the synthesis temperature on the performance of the synthesized catalyst. As the synthesis temperature increases from 70°C to 110°C, the EC conversion, DMC selectivity, and DMC yield show an increasing trend. This is attributed to an increase in the average kinetic energy of molecules with the reaction temperature, facilitating more frequent and high-energy collisions and thereby increasing the rate of chemical reactions. However, as the synthesis temperature continues to increase from 110°C to 130°C, the EC conversion, DMC selectivity, and DMC yield show a downward trend. Combined with the TG–MS analysis, it was observed that the alkyl side chain and carboxyl group of the imidazole ring undergo thermal decomposition at elevated reaction temperatures, leading to catalyst deactivation. Notably, when the synthesis temperature is 100°C, the EC conversion rate is 76.2 %, DMC selectivity and yield are 88.7 % and 67.6 %, respectively, and TOF is 10.2 h−1. Meanwhile, when the synthesis temperature is 110°C, the EC conversion rate is 77.6 %, DMC selectivity and yield are 88.1 % and 68.4 %, respectively, and TOF is 10.0 h−1. According to Table 1 , the alkalinity of the catalysts synthesized at 100°C and 110°C are 1.18 and 1.22 mmol/g, respectively. Considering industrial applications, 100°C is selected as the optimal synthesis temperature. Fig. 8 (b) displays the effect of the synthesis time on the performance of the obtained catalyst. As the synthesis time increases from 1 to 8 h, the EC conversion, DMC selectivity, and DMC yield initially increase and then decrease. When the synthesis time is 2 h, the EC conversion is 76.2 %, and DMC selectivity and yield reach their maximum values of 88.7 % and 67.6 %, respectively. Therefore, the optimal synthesis time is considered to be 2 h. To further study the effect of the synthesis time, the FT-IR spectra of PS–IMIL prepared at different synthesis times are shown in Fig. 9 . The results indicate that the intensity of the peak at 1558 cm−1 (ascribed to the C = N bond in the imidazole ring) is enhanced as the synthesis time increases from 2 to 8 h, whereas the intensity of the characteristic peak at 1674 cm−1 (ascribed to the C = O bond) decreased. These results indicate that with an increase in the synthesis time, alkyl side chains and active sites connected to the imidazole ring in PS–IMIL will decompose. The alkali amount (total number of alkaline sites per unit mass of catalyst) and strength of the as-prepared catalyst were measured using the Hammett indicator titration method and Equation S1, respectively. As presented in Table 1, at the same synthesis time of 2 h, the alkali content is increased with the synthesis temperature. This is because a high temperature can promote effective molecular collisions, increasing the number of active sites. Furthermore, a large number of active sites in turn increase the alkali content. Meanwhile, at a synthesis temperature of 100 °C, the alkali content first increases and then decreases with increasing synthesis time. As the synthesis time is increased from 1 to 2 h, the alkali content is increased from 1.06 to 1.18 mmol/g. This is because when the synthesis time is 1 h, the reaction remains incomplete. However, when the synthesis time is increased from 2 to 8 h, the alkali content is decreased. The FT-IR results indicate that a longer synthesis time will lead to the breakdown of the active sites. 3.5 Optimization of transesterification reaction conditions Temperature is a key parameter in transesterification reactions as it greatly influences the reaction rate and product selectivity. Generally, increasing the temperature can accelerate the reaction rate. Fig. 10 (a) shows the effect of the reaction temperature on the transesterification reaction, where 68°C is the azeotropic temperature, and the molar ratio of EC to MeOH is 1: 6. The results demonstrate that with an increase in the reaction temperature, the EC conversion, DMC selectivity, and DMC yield show an upward trend. Particularly, when the reaction temperature is increased from 30°C to 68°C, the DMC selectivity exhibits a rapid increase. This is because a high temperature is conducive to the conversion of MeOH to the methoxy group and a high methoxy concentration facilitates the ring-opening reaction of EC and cleavage of the C–O bonds between carbonyl groups. When the reaction temperature reaches 90°C, the DMC selectivity tends to stabilize, indicating that the reaction has approached equilibrium. The weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) is another key parameter in transesterification reactions. A higher WHSV leads to a shorter residence time of reactants on the catalyst surface, thereby leading to an incomplete reaction. Conversely, a small WHSV leads to a correspondingly long residence time of reactants on the catalyst surface, resulting in a complete reaction. Fig. 10 (b) shows the influence of the WHSV on the transesterification reaction. With an increase in the WHSV, the EC conversion, DMC selectivity, and DMC yield decrease. However, when the mass space velocity is increased to 15.0 h−1, the DMC yield is still 37.7 % and TOF is 17.1 h−1, indicating that PS–IMIL has excellent catalytic activity and can be employed for efficient and large-scale DMC production. 3.6 Evaluation of catalyst stability The stability of catalysts is extremely important for the durability and economic viability of catalytic reactions. Using highly stable catalysts can reduce the frequency and cost of replacements and minimize waste generation, it is crucial for the sustainable development of industrial catalytic processes. Fig. 11 demonstrates the catalytic performance of PS–IMIL for long-term use in EC and MeOH reactions. The results show that after 300 h of continuous use, the EC conversion, DMC selectivity, and DMC yield are 75.9 %, 83.5 %, and 63.4 %, respectively, consistent with the results obtained in the initial reaction stage. In addition, Fig. 4 (a) displays the FT-IR spectra of PS–IMIL after 300 h of continuous use, and the results show that the catalytic performance of PS–IMIL has no significant change compared with that before use, indicating that PS–IMIL has good stability. Fig. 12 (a) depicts the solid-state 13C NMR spectra of PS–IMIL after 300 h of continuous use. The solid-state 13C NMR spectrum of PS–IMIL after 300 h is similar to that before use, indicating that PS–IMIL maintains a stable structure. However, two peaks are observed at 18.9 and 57.2 ppm, which is attributable to the residue of EC on the PS–IMIL surface. Fig. 12 (b) shows the TG–DTA curves of PS–IMIL after 300 h of use, exhibiting four distinct weight-loss stages. The first decomposition stage ranges from room temperature to 114.8°C, with a mass loss of 3.6 %, which is attributable to the volatilization of residual DMC and adsorbed water. The second decomposition stage occurs from 126.5°C to 230.1°C, with a mass loss of 8.8 %, attributable to the thermal decomposition of the carboxyl group and alkyl side chain in the quaternary ammonium group. With continuous heating up to 362.8°C, the third decomposition stage is observed, with a mass loss of 17.4 %, which is attributable to the thermal decomposition of the imidazole ring. As the temperature rises to 600°C, the fourth decomposition stage is observed, with a mass loss of 51.6 %. This stage corresponds to the thermal decomposition of the resin. Ultimately, around 17.2 % of the mass remains, which can be attributable to the deposition of carbon. After 300 h of use, the decomposition temperature of PS–IMIL is lower compared to the catalyst before use. This can be attributed to the swelling of the resin, which facilitates the entry of heat and gas within the resin, thereby promoting the thermal decomposition reaction. In addition, the swelling of the resin increases the surface area and exposes more reaction sites, thereby accelerating thermal decomposition. Fig. 12 (c–d) show the SEM images of PS–IMIL after use at different magnifications. The surface is rougher and contains more massive particles compared with that before use, which correspond to residual EC. The EDS mapping images are shown in Fig. 12 (e), the C, N, O, and Cl elements are evenly distributed, indicating that the elemental composition does not change after use. These results indicated that PS–IMIL has excellent catalytic stability. 3.7 Application of PS–IMIL in various transesterification reactions Fig. 13 shows the catalytic performance of PS–IMIL in various transesterification reactions, and the corresponding equations are included in equations E1 ∼ 6 (as shown in Supplementary Material). When PS–IMIL are used as catalysts for the transesterification reaction between EC and MeOH, the EC conversion reaches 76.2 %, with the DMC selectivity and yield of 88.7 % and 67.6 %, respectively. In a transesterification reaction involving EC and EtOH, the EC conversion is 68.7 % and DEC selectivity and yield are 31.7 % and 21.8 %, respectively. These results indicate that the efficiency of the transesterification reaction of EC and MeOH is higher than that of EC and EtOH. This is because the O–H bond energy in MeOH molecules is lower than that in EtOH [45], facilitating easy transformation into methoxy groups. In a transesterification reaction between PC and MeOH, the PC conversion reaches 45.5 %, with the DMC selectivity and yield of 81.4 % and 37.1 %, respectively. This indicates that the efficiency of the transesterification reaction of EC and MeOH is higher than that of PC and MeOH, attributable to the presence of –CH3 in PC, which not only reduces electron delocalization in the C–O bond but also increases steric hindrance, thereby decreasing the transesterification efficiency of the reaction. When PS–IMIL catalyzes the transesterification reaction between DMC and EtOH, the DMC conversion is 83.5 %, with the DEC selectivity and yield of 58.0 % and 48.4 %, respectively. When PS–IMIL catalyzes transesterification between DEC and MeOH, the DEC conversion is 86.7 %, with DMC selectivity and yield of 75.1 % and 65.1 %, respectively. These results indicate that the efficiency of the transesterification reaction between DEC and MeOH is higher than that between DEC and EtOH, attributable to the lower O–H bond energy of MeOH molecules, which is exploited by PS–IMIL to activate MeOH into methoxy groups and subsequently promote the ring-opening reaction of EC. In the transesterification reaction between DMC and DEC to produce ethyl methyl carbonate (EMC), the DMC conversion is 41.1 %. Since no byproduct is formed in this reaction, the EMC selectivity reaches 99.9 %, and the yield of EMC is 41.0 %. These results demonstrated that the PS–IMIL not only exhibits good catalytic activity for the transesterification of alcohols with esters but also shows excellent catalytic performance for the reaction of esters with another esters. Reaction conditions: EC-MeOH: temperature = 68°C, WHSV = 5 h−1, nEC: nMeOH = 1: 6; EC-EtOH: temperature = 82°C, WHSV = 1 h−1, nEC: nEtOH = 1:6; PC-MeOH: temperature = 70°C, WHSV = 1 h−1, nPC: nMeOH = 1: 6; DMC-EtOH: temperature = 95°C, WHSV = 1 h−1, nDMC: nEtOH = 1: 6; DEC-MeOH: temperature = 95°C, WHSV = 1 h−1, nDEC: nMeOH = 1: 6; DMC-DEC: temperature = 110°C, WHSV = 1 h−1, nDMC: nDEC = 1: 1; In all the reactions, the mass of the catalyst is 4 g. 3.8 Mechanism of the transesterification reaction between EC and MeOH catalyzed by PS–IMIL To determine the transesterification reaction mechanism of EC and MeOH catalyzed by PS–IMIL, GC–MS was used to analyze the fixed-bed effluent. Based on our previous study [46], the results show that fixed-bed effluent primarily contains EC, MeOH, DMC, and EG. In addition, hydroxyethyl methyl carbonate (HEMC) and di(hydroxyethyl) carbonate (DHEMC) are detected. Therefore, the transesterification reaction mechanism of EC and MeOH catalyzed by PS–IMIL is inferred, as shown in Fig. 14 . Active sites in PS–IMIL can capture protons from the hydroxyl group of MeOH, leading to the conversion of MeOH to the methoxy group. Because the carbonyl C atom in EC has low electronegativity, the obtained methoxy groups can further react with EC to form an intermediate (a). However, the structure of intermediate (a) is unstable, therefore, it will undergo a rapid ring-opening and proton-transfer-reaction, resulting in the formation of HEMC. Subsequently, HEMC continues to react with methoxy groups to produce an intermediate (b), which can also undergo an elimination reaction to produce DMC and EG anions. Specifically, glycol anions can participate in two reactions: steps 5 and 6. In step 5, glycol anions react with MeOH to produce EG and methoxy groups. In step 6, EG anions react with the HEMC system to obtain an intermediate (c), which can also undergo an elimination reaction to produce DHEMC and the methoxy group due to its unstable structure. 3.9 Study on reaction kinetics To investigate the reaction efficiency of the transesterification of EC and MeOH catalyzed by PS-IMIL, the kinetics and related kinetic parameters were studied. The specific calculation process is placed in Supplementary Material. According to the results, the linear relationship between lnk and 1/T is shown in Fig. 15 (b). According to the intercept, the pre-exponential factor A is 38948.7 min−1. Additionally, according to the slope, the activation energy Ea is 36.0 kJ·mol−1. The lower activation energy compared to the reported catalyst (as shown in Table S1) indicates that PS-IMIL has a better ability to catalyze the transesterification of EC and MeOH. 3.10 Comparison of catalytic activity At present, heterogeneous catalysts widely used in the transesterification of EC and MeOH can be roughly divided into several categories, such as metal oxides, zeolites, hydrotalcite, supported ionic liquids, poly ionic liquids, and some representative novel materials. To further understand the catalytic performance of these heterogeneous catalysts, a brief comparison of PS–IMIL with various reported catalysts for the transesterification reaction of EC and MeOH is summarized in Table 2 . For metal oxides, although CeO2 demonstrates good catalytic performance, the harsh reaction conditions require specialized equipment and result in energy waste. When MgO and MgO–P–Na2CO3 are used as catalysts, the DMC yield is 2.5 % and 27.0 %, respectively. MgO–CeO2 shows outstanding catalytic performance in a fixed-bed reactor; despite a high reaction temperature of 150°C, the DMC yield reaches 64.0 %. Additionally, when SrO/CeO2 is used as a catalyst, the DMC yield reaches 87.0 %. However, a high reaction temperature and a long reaction time limit its industrial application. K2O/M−ZrO2−C achieves a high DMC yield at 85°C, but its preparation procedure is complex. When MgO is supported on the NaY surface, the resulting MgO/NaY demonstrates excellent catalytic activity, achieving a DMC yield of 88.9 % and a TOF of 143.6 h−1. This is attributable to the high specific surface area of NaY zeolite, which enhances the dispersion of MgO particles and prevents the aggregation of active sites. Similarly, Li: NaY achieves a satisfactory catalytic effect in a short time, and the DMC yield reaches 89.0 %. However, a common drawback of metal oxides and supported catalysts is their tendency to undergo chemical changes and lose active sites, leading to a short lifespan. When NaZSM-5 is used as a catalyst, the DMC yield reaches 77.0 %. This superior catalytic performance is attributable to the presence of sodium (alkali metal) ions. Hydrotalcites are commonly used as catalysts for transesterification reactions. For example, when MgxAl–NO3 is employed as a catalyst, the DMC yield is 58.0 %, with a TOF of 65.2 h−1. When NiAl–SiO3 and NiAl–CO3 are used as catalysts, the DMC yield is 58.0 % and 67.2 %, respectively, at 90°C. Additionally, when Mg3Fe0.85Ce0.15 is utilized as a catalyst, the DMC yield is 87.0 %, with a TOF of 325.4 h−1. These results indicate that hydrotalcite exhibits excellent catalytic performance in promoting the conversion of EC to DMC. Nonetheless, the active sites of hydrotalcite are prone to loss and the regeneration procedure is complex, thereby impeding its substantial progress in recent years. As a substitute for traditional transesterification catalysts, ionic liquids have emerged as a new development trend recently. To address the challenges associated with the separation of homogeneous ionic liquids from the respective products, immobilized ionic liquids and polyionic liquids are regarded as effective solutions. Immobilized ionic-liquid catalysts, such as PS–IMC4IM, show high catalytic activity. At 68°C for 3 h, the DMC yield is 52.7 %, with a TOF of 76.7 h−1. PS–IMC4IM exhibits excellent catalytic stability, with no change in the activity or structure after continuous reaction for 2000 h. SBA-15-[SmIm]OH shows good catalytic activity, achieving a DMC yield of 66.2 % and a TOF of 6.5 h−1 at 65°C after reaction for 5 h. However, the extensive use of these catalysts leads to a wastage of resources. Additionally, THA–MS41 and BMImBr–AS demonstrate excellent catalytic performance, obtaining DMC yields of 76.3 % and 72.6 %, respectively. However, their complex preparation procedures and harsh reaction conditions limit large-scale applications. Polyionic liquids have demonstrated excellent catalytic performance. When using poly[VBIm–VBA–DVIm]-2.5 % as a catalyst, the DMC yield reaches 78.6 % at 110°C and a reaction time of 4 h. [DVCPIL][PHO] exhibits excellent catalytic performance in DMC synthesis. However, the extensive use of these catalysts also causes a waste of resources. PILs–FL is a solid spherical particle obtained via ionic-liquid polymerization. When used as a catalyst, the DMC yield reaches 93.7 % at 90°C. This is a novel attempt with good reference value. Further, when poly[VOIm–AA–DVIm] is used as a catalyst at 120°C and a reaction time of 6 h, the DMC yield is 76.6 %. Other heterogeneous catalysts with novel structures also demonstrate excellent catalytic ability. For instance, when eg–C3N4–NH3 is employed as a catalyst, the DMC yield is 60.3 % at 120 °C and a reaction time of 4 h. In addition, using CN–MCF as a catalyst results in a DMC yield of 77.8 % at 160°C and a reaction time of 6 h. Moreover, when ZnNbCl/eg–C3N4 is used as a catalyst, the DMC yield reaches 80.1 % at 140°C and a reaction time of 4 h. Finally, when Nb–CN is employed as a catalyst, the DMC yield reaches 53.8 % at 140°C and a reaction time of 4 h. Notably, when using these materials as catalysts, the reaction conditions are very harsh. This imposes stringent equipment requirements and increases operational difficulties. This study reported PS–IMIL as a heterogeneous NHC–CO2 catalyst that demonstrates exceptional performance. The results indicate that when PS–IMIL is used as a catalyst, the DMC yield reaches 48.3 % at 68°C and a reaction time of 3 h in a three-necked flask, with a TOF of 51.7 h−1. Compared with other catalysts, the preparation procedure of PS–IMIL is simple and environmentally friendly. Moreover, PS–IMIL exhibits outstanding catalytic activity and stability, making it highly suitable for industrial applications. These remarkable characteristics position PS–IMIL as a promising material in the field of green chemistry. 4 Conclusions In this study, an in-situ green catalyst-synthesis technique was proposed and a heterogeneous catalyst, PS–IMIL, was successfully synthesized. PS–IMIL exhibits several desirable characteristics, such as being metal- and halogen-free, containing NHC–CO2 functional groups, and demonstrating strong alkalinity, as well as excellent catalytic ability and stability. The structure and properties of PS–IMIL were analyzed using various characterization techniques and experiments. The results indicate that PS–IMIL demonstrates excellent thermal stability, catalytic activity, and lifespan. Based on the catalyst preparation mechanism, the ring-opening reaction of EC and SN2 reaction between EC and PS–IM are crucial for synthesizing PS–IMIL. The carboxylate groups in PS–IMIL serve as active sites for promoting the transesterification reaction between EC and MeOH. When the molar ratio of EC to MeOH is 1: 6 and WHSV is 5 h−1, the optimized in-situ catalyst synthesis conditions are as follows: synthesis temperature of 100°C and time of 2 h. Under these conditions, PS–IMIL exhibits excellent catalytic activity and stability and is suitable for various transesterification reactions. The kinetic results demonstrate that the pre-exponential factor A is 38948.67 min−1 and activation energy is 35.97 kJ·mol−1. coredata.dc:description: N-heterocyclic carbene CO2 adducts (NHC–CO2) are typical zwitterionic ionic liquid compounds, known for their strong nucleophilicity and significant catalytic ability. However, NHC–CO2 is sensitive to water, and its complex and polluting preparation process limits its widespread application. Furthermore, most reported NHC–CO2 compounds function as homogeneous catalysts, posing considerable challenges for separation. In this study, an in-situ green synthesis method was employed to develop a heterogeneous NHC–CO2 catalyst, PS–IMIL. This approach not only prevents direct contact between the catalyst and water but also simplifies the preparation process and mitigates environmental pollution. The synthesis conditions of PS–IMIL were optimized, and its structure and properties were analyzed. Furthermore, the synthesis mechanism of PS–IMIL was investigated, and its kinetics were also studied. The results indicate that the interaction between the material ethylene carbonate (EC) and the precursor is crucial for the in-situ synthesis of PS–IMIL. The prepared PS–IMIL not only preserves the catalytic ability of NHC–CO2 but also exhibits characteristics of being metal- and halogen-free. Remarkably, the catalytic activity and structure of PS–IMIL remain unchanged after 300 h of continuous use in dimethyl carbonate (DMC) production. Compared to similar catalysts, PS–IMIL exhibits excellent catalytic activity and stability. This study provides a solid theoretical and practical reference for the development of heterogeneous NHC–CO2 catalysts. The synthesized PS–IMIL demonstrates significant potential for the industrial production of DMC and other carbonate esters.
